summary: This document is an internal DOJ report from May 20, 2021, detailing the USAO-SDNY's plan to offer deferred prosecution agreements to two correctional officers, Tova Noel and Michael Thomas. They were charged in 2019 for falsifying records on the night Jeffrey Epstein died by suicide at the Manhattan Correctional Center. The agreements require admissions of guilt, cooperation with an OIG investigation, and community service.

keyFacts: Two correctional officers, Tova Noel and Michael Thomas, were charged with falsifying count and round forms on the night Jeffrey Epstein died by suicide at the Manhattan Correctional Center.

The USAO-SDNY determined that offering deferred prosecution agreements was consistent with the interests of justice, citing the officers' mitigating personal circumstances and Department practice in similar cases.

As part of the deferred prosecution agreements, Noel and Thomas must admit guilt, cooperate truthfully with the Office of Inspector General's investigation, and complete 100 hours of community service.
The falsification of records by the officers occurred prior to their discovery of Epstein's body on August 10, 2019.
The agreement does not preclude administrative action or termination by the Bureau of Prisons against the officers.
